Problem:
Consider a linear transformation on a vector space using a matrix M and its exponential \\(e^{Mt}\\) which acts on vectors in the space. We investigate the effects of initial transformations \\(f(x) = e^{Nt}x\\), where N is another matrix, on the temporal evolution of vectors.

Given an initial application of \\(f(x) = e^{Nt}x\\) on a vector \\(x_0\\) at t = 0, untouched thereafter, will the transformation under \\(e^{Mt}\\) for a time T result in the same vector as if only \\(e^{Mt}\\) had been applied directly to \\(x_0\\) at t = 0?
Explanation: Applying \\(f(x) = e^{Nt}x\\) at t = 0 modifies the initial vector, and as it evolves under \\(e^{Mt}\\), the trajectory depends on both N and M. The result depends on the interaction between N and M, generally leading to a different endpoint at time T than if \\(x_0\\) was only evolved under \\(e^{Mt}\\).
